{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3582725,"name":"Sreyan Das","username":"sdas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sdas/{size}/242589_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-07T17:52:10.945Z","cooked":"

Hello, I’m looking for other teams that use Photon Vision to provide some insights on what might cause extreme latency increases that are momentary and unpredictable.

github.com

GitHub - MARSProgramming/Marvin18: marvin 18

marvin 18

This is our code. Our vision code is in the “IntegratedVision” file but for the most part there is nothing “custom” we have done except for the following, which are things i feel like could contribute the most to our latency variability issues:

  • Set the # of threads to 7 (our coprocessor has 8, and PhotonVision says they recommend running one under the maximum at most, and I was wondering if this could be contributing to the issue.
  • we are using the experimental photon vision “turbo button”
  • NetworkTableInstance.getDefault().getBooleanTopic(“/photonvision/use_new_cscore_frametime”).publish().set(true);

I was wondering if this too could be the reason why we are having all the issues.

github.com/PhotonVision/photonvision

Ingest wpilib!7609 and add turbo button

PhotonVision:main ← mcm001:cscore-frame-time
opened 08:17PM - 28 Dec 24 UTC
mcm001
+425 -36

Now that https://github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib/pull/7572 and https://github.c…om/wpilibsuite/allwpilib/pull/7609 have been merged: - Adds a magic hidden button to enable the new frame grabber behavior by adding a boolean topic at `/photonvision/use_new_cscore_frametime`. Toggle this to true to maybe increase FPS at the cost of latency variability - Bumps WPILib to ingest https://github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib/pull/7609 , but doesn't currently provide any user feedback about the time source. I don't think that reporting this super matters?

I think it is the latter but I was wondering that teams who do use this, if you leave it enabled, did you notice major issues with any alignment you were running? I feel like it might be the root cause of our issues.

The primary camera we are using is “reef” I believe. That one does all the processing we need

From FRC_20250405_141305_TNKN_Q68.wpilog, it looks like time sync stayed alive (see /photonvision/reef_cam/rawBytes/metadata/timeSinceLastPong and the /photonvision/.timesync/reef/ subtable), but sequence number drops to 0 between 264 and 274 seconds into the log. After the sequence counter resumes, it starts back from 15217 to 15218. I suspect that this logic is responsible: photonvision/photon-core/src/main/java/org/photonvision/vision/frame/provider/CpuImageProcessor.java at f92cf62a546648e0423c28e285b6cf333c9abdc9 · PhotonVision/photonvision · GitHub
Do your PhotonVision logs contain a lot of “Input was empty!” messages?

I’m not sure where to find that information, would it be logged in the driver station?

You can find it on the PhotonVision dashboard. There should be a button to download logs, which you can then look at. You can also view them live, but that might not be as helpful if this isn’t a currently occurring issue.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-04-07T22:16:18.317Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":137,"readers_count":136,"score":42.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":498306,"topic_slug":"photonvision-reported-latency-jumps","display_username":"Sreyan Das","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":63767,"username":"Sam948","name":"Sam","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sam948/{size}/261363_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62175,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"programmer for 2614"},"post_url":"/t/photonvision-reported-latency-jumps/498306/8","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3583135,"name":"HighClimber1768","username":"HighClimber1768","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/highclimber1768/{size}/2121_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-07T23:26:45.152Z","cooked":"

We had this exact problem. We solved it by

  1. Not allowing photonvision to process more than five April tags at a time.

  2. disabling the WPI Lib watchdog.

Thanks for team 190 for helping us with this problem.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-04-08T09:46:10.640Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":98,"readers_count":97,"score":24.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":498306,"topic_slug":"photonvision-reported-latency-jumps","display_username":"Sreyan Das","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"/uploads/short-url/zFTKGMxswypiI5IBLSoPUzSJ426.zip","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":37738,"username":"thatmattguy","name":"Matt","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thatmattguy/{size}/222358_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62175,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"programmer for 2614"},"post_url":"/t/photonvision-reported-latency-jumps/498306/11","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3583717,"name":"Matt","username":"thatmattguy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thatmattguy/{size}/222358_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-08T14:28:42.870Z","cooked":"

in photonvision-journalctl.txt, the lines from KernelLogLogger are of particular interest to me. For example, I see

Oct 31 22:28:08 reef java[659]: [2024-10-31 22:28:08] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:28:07.638067+00:00 reef kernel: usb 4-1: USB disconnect, device number 3
Oct 31 22:28:08 reef java[659]: [2024-10-31 22:28:08] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:28:07.641367+00:00 reef kernel: uvcvideo 4-1:1.1: Failed to resubmit video URB (-19).
Oct 31 22:28:08 reef java[659]: [2024-10-31 22:28:08] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:28:07.954778+00:00 reef kernel: usb 4-1: new high-speed USB device number 4 using ehci-platform
Oct 31 22:28:08 reef java[659]: [2024-10-31 22:28:08] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:28:08.124742+00:00 reef kernel: usb 4-1: New USB device found, idVendor=0c45, idProduct=6366, bcdDevice= 1.00
Oct 31 22:28:08 reef java[659]: [2024-10-31 22:28:08] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:28:08.124758+00:00 reef kernel: usb 4-1: New USB device strings: Mfr=2, Product=1, SerialNumber=3

And also

<camera starts happily>
<cscore barfs>
Oct 31 22:41:07 reef java[661]: [2024-10-31 22:41:07] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:41:06.762977+00:00 reef kernel: usb usb6-port1: disabled by hub (EMI?), re-enabling...
Oct 31 22:41:07 reef java[661]: [2024-10-31 22:41:07] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:41:06.762995+00:00 reef kernel: usb 6-1: USB disconnect, device number 2
Oct 31 22:41:07 reef java[661]: [2024-10-31 22:41:07] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:41:06.766288+00:00 reef kernel: uvcvideo 6-1:1.1: Failed to resubmit video URB (-19).
Oct 31 22:41:07 reef java[661]: [2024-10-31 22:41:07] [Camera - USBFrameProvider - reef_cam] [ERROR] Error grabbing image: timed out getting frame

<some time later>

Oct 31 22:41:11 reef java[661]: [2024-10-31 22:41:11] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:41:10.609634+00:00 reef kernel: usb 6-1: New USB device found, idVendor=0c45, idProduct=6366, bcdDevice= 1.00
Oct 31 22:41:11 reef java[661]: [2024-10-31 22:41:11] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:41:10.609646+00:00 reef kernel: usb 6-1: New USB device strings: Mfr=2, Product=1, SerialNumber=3
Oct 31 22:41:11 reef java[661]: [2024-10-31 22:41:11] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:41:10.609647+00:00 reef kernel: usb 6-1: Product: Arducam OV9782 USB Camera
Oct 31 22:41:11 reef java[661]: [2024-10-31 22:41:11] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:41:10.609648+00:00 reef kernel: usb 6-1: Manufacturer: Arducam Technology Co.
<fails to re-enumerate>

This isn’t super helpful – it doesn’t rule out much – but it’s good to confirm that the camera itself is disconnecting from your coprocessor. Things to investigate might include a loose USB connection, ESD damage to the camera or orange pi, and power supply quality.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-04-09T16:58:54.382Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":55,"readers_count":54,"score":31.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":498306,"topic_slug":"photonvision-reported-latency-jumps","display_username":"Sreyan Das","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":37738,"username":"thatmattguy","name":"Matt","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thatmattguy/{size}/222358_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62175,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"programmer for 2614"},"post_url":"/t/photonvision-reported-latency-jumps/498306/14","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3586152,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/8072_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-10T12:58:01.489Z","cooked":"
sdas:

loose USB but it’s unlikely.

It’s important to remember that PhotonVision doesn’t have full control of the camera stack, from photons up to the RIO. It’s reliant upon the camera hardware, USB connection, USB driver, Camera Driver, CSCore abstracitons, and the Linux operating system to supply it information about what cameras are connected, and what pixels are which colors.

The message in your logs indicates the linux kernel is having trouble communicating with the Camera, and is therefor unable to supply frames to PhotonVision.

There’s a lot possible causes here, but something important to remember: if the root cause was in the linux kernel or the driver itself, it would show up in the logs of everyone using it. Sample size of a few, this is the first time I’ve seen this specific error message.

The explanation for why your observed behavior is different than other teams most likely lies in things that are unique to your team.

Assuming you’re using the stock PhotonVision Orange Pi 5 image without changing software, most of your stack should be the same as others.

However, things that always could be different include:

  1. Whether or not a cable is properly seated in its connector
  2. The way the USB cable is plugged in and routed between camera and board
  3. A specific solder joint on any board being intact

etc. etc. etc.

Hence the recommendation of where to look: The most likely explanation for a unique error is in the uniqueness expected in each team.

etc.

Some cameras have THIS and some don’t.
